https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/60449/ : SUCCESS
We need to get buy-in from maintainers of other platforms that were using it in the original method. We need broader testing than just YosemiteV2.
Sure, I am only able to test in YosemiteV2 platform. If possible, could you please help to test in other platforms where this implementation is used.

Hi Jayashree,

I have a few comments and queries. You need a change to stop the udev invocation of the service as well right? Is there a patch somewhere for that (can you link to it?) I'm interested in how that patch allows phosphor-led-sysfs to continue working on existing systems using it without migrating them to EntityManager.

In existing platforms, migration needs to be done from udev rule to entity-manager configuration inorder to support the physical LEDs.

The below patch is submitted for meta-phosphor change.

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/56947

Not all systems use entity-manager.  I'd prefer we find a mechanism to still inform the daemon of new LEDs via udev.  There is no reason to lean entirely on entity-manager for this, especially since there can be lag between the entity-manager config and the device probing to enable the appropriate GPIOs / LEDs.

Right, I think we need to split up the patches adding any EM support so that the daemon can still work without EM. This necessitates leaving some udev support in-place. One way that this might work is that udev runs a helper executable that calls a DBus API on the phosphor-led-sysfs daemon to add a new LED. This helper could be some C++-based binary or just a shell script that invokes busctl. phosphor-led-sysfs can then funnel actions from EM or udev into the one handler implementation.

It's possible that with this approach you could implement what you need without any EM bits required, and we can kick that can down the road until we need to describe add-in cards with LEDs.

I feel like I suggested this (and EM) on the design doc some time back? I think I leaned the EM way because it is more general, but I don't think I ever suggested we drop the current udev mechanism.

phosphor-led-sysfs daemon needs to support both udev and EM configs mechanism.

udev event needs to support physical LEDs, therefore, it will not break the existing platform. udev rule can invoke the phosphor-led-sysfs daemon through script/binary by calling DBus API under single service.

EM config can also be supported to create physical LEDs dbus path under single service and not disturbing udev event.

Is my above understanding is correct ?

Yes, we need to at least retain udev support to prevent breaking existing platforms that use phosphor-led-sysfs in its current implementation.

EM support is something you can add if you need EM; this will give you the capability to describe LEDs on pluggable cards (which you shouldn't do via the devicetree).
ok, I will work on phosphor-led-sysfs daemon to support both udev and entity-manager and submit the patch as soon as possible.

Just to be clear, only add EM support if you need it. It's possible to rework the udev support consolidate the processes without requiring EM while also being backwards compatible with existing systems. And if that's enough to get your problems solved, then we can leave EM support to someone else.

> And if that's enough to get your problems solved, then we can leave EM support to someone else.

Fundamentally what we're looking for is a way to combine N GPIOs into 1 LED (with color).  If we can do that in an automatic way (based on name) we don't need EM.  If you (Andrew) are opposed to doing that in an automated way, we need EM to specify the composition.
The design doc is now updated to support udev event and entity-manager is not required now, since LEDs are configured in existing platforms via devicetree

This is a drive by comment - I'm not looking for any changes.

> automatic way (based on name)

Is it any more automatic to require specific naming conventions in the device tree?

Additionally, EM configurations can already have schema verification applied.

FWIW, one of the goals of entity manager is to consolidate where this kind of information lives, to make new system ports easier.

Well, I'd prefer we didn't use something like names. But, if it means dragging EM into your system just for handling LEDs then I think I could live with the name hack whilst also supporting EM to do it properly at some point down the track.

Why are we using std::error instead of phosphor-logging?  Who is expected to ever see these messages?  Are there any cases where we should be throwing an exception instead and causing the application to restart?  I suspect we have a bunch of instances in this change where bad entity-manager config just goes silently unnoticed until someone really digs into their system.  This is not a good approach to me.
Why is this static_cast necessary?  Isn't that already the type?
It looks like now we are only adding exactly 1 match, so why do we need the unique_ptr and vector and everything?  Can't we hold a match_t directly in the object?

A minor improvement:

auto [path, interfaces] = message.unpack<object_path, LedData>();

I guess std::get<>() can throw an exception.
Possible to use std::get_if<>() instead ?

There is a whole lot of work being done here that is not necessary.

1. getDbusName formulates the last part of the path from the device/color/function, but we already did that on line 135.
2. sdbusplus already has operations to do path transformation to ensure that only valid characters are used.

Please use sdbusplus::object_path and its `operator /=` in order to put together the path, so that the correct transformations are used.
Do we really need a std::unique_ptr here? Also why can't we embed the objects directly in the map? And then just use an emplace() style call?
I think we moved away from creating object managers at the root. I've asked here: https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/867820390406422538/1014753835643842601
I have seen the discussions in discord. Whether can we change from root("/") to "/xyz/openbmc_project/led" for creating object managers ?
Yes, whatever the first path is after openbmc_project for the objects that this daemon will create.

There is no need for sdeventplus here.  It is a bunch of extra code and dependency for no good reason.  Just use bus::process_loop().


I don't understand why you even added this.  The original code worked just fine with the while-loop.  All bus.process_loop() is is exactly the while loop that previously existed.

I'm not finding these used anywhere, but I could be failing to search in Gerrit.

Why are these flat_map instead of std::unordered_map?
These are used to handle the sdbusplus message. flat_map is used based on the reference in other repos. I will change to std::unordered_map in next patchset.

Let's drop 'Sysfs' here. `...Configuration.Led` (or LED, whatever the convention is) is enough.

Regardless, you need to propose a new schema for EntityManager and get that merged before we can merge this patch.

Ack

Will submit a new patch for LED schema in entity-manager.

> Let's drop 'Sysfs' here. `...Configuration.Led` (or LED, whatever the convention is) is enough.

Except there is a difference between the physical LED config and the virtual groups, right?  How do we ensure that people understand the difference?  I don't know if "Configuration.Led" is sufficient.

Maybe "Configuration.Led" isn't sufficient, but I feel like it's wrong to embed implementation details like "sysfs" into the API? Do we need "Configuration.Led" and "Configuration.VirtualLed" or "Configuration.ComposedLed"?
I see no use for this being added.

Can you separate this bit out into its own patch? That will clean up the noise.

That said, how does the test suite fair with this?

Looking at the Jenkins output, it blows up:

 [10/12] Compiling C++ object phosphor-ledcontroller.p/controller.cpp.o

> Can you separate this bit out into its own patch? That will clean up the noise.
> 

Will submit a new patch for this.



> That said, how does the test suite fair with this?
> 
> Looking at the Jenkins output, it blows up:

I am working on resolving test suite for this implementation. Will change the test suite once it is completed.

This is the cause of the build failure. Please make sure to run `meson test` locally; we can't submit the changes until that passes.

I prefer composition over inheritance as it helps partition the concepts and keeps the code easy to test.

I'll let Andrew decide for sure, but it doesn't seem to me like this should be a free-standing commit.  It takes a working repository and turns it into a non-working one.  We now launch a daemon that does nothing.  I guess as long as we are careful to only merge the whole sequence that is fine, but it seems odd to now have a main function that effectively does nothing.

Agree with Patrick here. I've tried to outline in the past how I expect the series to be structured. Each change must stand on its own. A patch may make incremental progress towards a larger goal but not at the expense of existing functionality. With this in mind, you may need to re-order the prior patches changing the service and udev files around so they're later in the series, as they refer to things that don't yet exist at the time.
I have submitted patches by reordering to maintain the existing functionality.

Apologize for not changing here. It is changed in the below patch. https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-led-sysfs/+/57455

Updated in this patch as well.
This should not be pass-by-reference.  Just pass a moved unique_ptr into this function (take a unique_ptr by value).

Hi Andrew,

Please provide your suggestions on this patch.

Thanks.
Okay, I've reworded the commit message on this one. The current commit message wasn't really aligned with what the patch was doing. Let me know what you think
